title: Iron Overdose & Poisoning: Symptoms, Risks, and Treatment
author: Hirania Luzardo

sections.heading: What Is Iron Poisoning?
content: Iron poisoning happens when someone swallows too much of something that contains iron, most often vitamins or other supplements.
Sudden, or acute, iron poisoning mainly involves children under 6. These children may not be able or willing to tell you what and how much they swallowed.
Iron supplements are widely used and come as drops, syrup, elixir, capsules, or tablets. Many adult multivitamin formulas contain iron. Prenatal vitamins have some of the highest amounts.
You can buy many iron supplements without a prescription. They come in containers that may or may not have safety caps.
Cases of iron poisoning — especially in young children — have declined since the 1990s, thanks to better labeling and safer packaging. But it's still a serious risk.
What should parents know about iron poisoning in kids?

"The most important things to tell the emergency provider are what type of iron was taken, how much, and when. This helps us determine exactly how much iron was ingested, and if it is a toxic amount for the size of the patient. As few as a handful of pills could potentially be dangerous, especially for children," says Lauren Elizabeth Siewny, MD, an emergency medicine specialist at Duke University Hospital in Durham, N.C.
Sleepiness and fatigue are early signs of iron poisoning. Try to find out how much iron your child swallowed, and seek emergency medical help right away. (Photo Credit: Александр Марко/Dreamstime)
bullets: The amount of iron that causes poisoning depends on the child's size. A dose that's safe for an 8-year-old could be dangerous for a 3-year-old. Symptoms usually start when a child takes more than 20 milligrams of iron per kilogram of their body weight (about 9 milligrams of iron for every pound of their body weight).

A child may show no symptoms after eating or drinking an iron supplement — the only evidence may be an open bottle. If you know or think that your child swallowed iron, call a poison control center or go to the ER right away.

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning Causes
content: The most common cause of iron poisoning is when someone accidentally eats or drinks too much of a supplement that contains iron. This may happen because i ron pills can look like candy to children. Although rare, intentional iron overdose can happen.

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning Symptoms
content: Symptoms of iron poisoning show up in stages. They often start with belly pain, vomiting, and diarrhea .
Early symptoms of iron poisoning

Iron overdose symptoms usually show up within the first six hours. "Typically, within the first few hours, patients will present with gastrointestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain ; vomiting, which can have blood in it; diarrhea or black stools; and even lethargy," says Odaimy Cervantes, MD, family medicine physician at Baptist Health South Florida in Miami.
Other early symptoms of iron poisoning include:

Even if your child feels better or only has mild symptoms, they should still go to the ER. "A doctor needs to make sure the poisoning isn't getting worse and help prevent serious problems," says Siewny. About 6-24 hours after the overdose, symptoms may appear to improve. But without the right treatment, they can worsen again.
bullets: Blood in the vomit or poop

But without the right treatment, they can worsen again.

sections.heading: Severe iron poisoning symptoms
content: About 12-48 hours after an iron overdose, serious symptoms of iron poisoning may show up. They include:
"The most life-threatening complications are kidney and liver failure, respiratory failure, nervous system dysfunction, bowel obstruction, coma, and even death," says Cervantes.
bullets: Liver failure (two to five days later, the liver could stop working)
Metabolic acidosis, in which too many acids build up in your blood

content_blocks.text: About 12-48 hours after an iron overdose, serious symptoms of iron poisoning may show up. They include:

Metabolic acidosis, in which too many acids build up in your blood

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
content: Call your doctor or poison control center, or go directly to the closest hospital's emergency department if you think your child has swallowed something with iron in it, even if they show no symptoms. Provide this information, if possible:
You can reach your local poison control center by calling the toll-free national Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222). They'll connect you with experts in poisoning, who will guide you further.
bullets: The name of the product they swallowed, or better yet, its container

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning Diagnosis
content: Doctors usually diagnose iron poisoning by observing your child. If they look normal and have no symptoms for six hours, the doctor may decide that they either didn't eat or drink any iron or took too little to be harmful.

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning Diagnosis
content: Doctors usually diagnose iron poisoning by observing your child. If they look normal and have no symptoms for six hours, the doctor may decide that they either didn't eat or drink any iron or took too little to be harmful.

content_blocks.text: Doctors usually diagnose iron poisoning by observing your child. If they look normal and have no symptoms for six hours, the doctor may decide that they either didn't eat or drink any iron or took too little to be harmful.

content: The doctor may draw blood to check:

The doctor may also order an X-ray of your child's abdomen to confirm whether there are iron pills in the gastrointestinal tract. But the pills don't always show up on an X-ray. Lab tests and scans also don't always clearly detect iron poisoning. And some tests take too long to help with quick treatment decisions.
How much iron a child swallowed can help doctors guess how serious the poisoning might be.

"A dangerous overdose is considered a blood level over 500 mcg/dL, but it depends on the type of iron ingested and the weight of the patient," says Cervantes. Usually, a dose below 20 mg/kg will be asymptomatic. Anything over 60mg/kg will lead to serious reactions."
"There are still not well-established values for what the minimum, maximum, and toxic doses of iron are," he says.

content_blocks.text: The doctor may draw blood to check:

The doctor may also order an X-ray of your child's abdomen to confirm whether there are iron pills in the gastrointestinal tract. But the pills don't always show up on an X-ray. Lab tests and scans also don't always clearly detect iron poisoning. And some tests take too long to help with quick treatment decisions.
How much iron a child swallowed can help doctors guess how serious the poisoning might be.

"A dangerous overdose is considered a blood level over 500 mcg/dL, but it depends on the type of iron ingested and the weight of the patient," says Cervantes. Usually, a dose below 20 mg/kg will be asymptomatic. Anything over 60mg/kg will lead to serious reactions."
"There are still not well-established values for what the minimum, maximum, and toxic doses of iron are," he says.

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning Treatment
content: The first thing your doctor will do is ensure the child with iron poisoning symptoms is breathing normally. Then, they'll likely give the child a liquid (laxative) to help clean out their bowel.

Serious cases often require IV (intravenous) chelation therapy . This involves a series of IVs with deferoxamine mesylate ( Desferal ), a chemical that binds to the extra iron in the blood so your child's body can get rid of it through their pee. Doctors can also give deferoxamine as a shot, but they usually use an IV because it's easier to control the dose. Common side effects of deferoxamine treatment include red-orange pee and low blood pressure . This treatment usually lasts about 24 hours.

Your doctor may consider pumping of the stomach (orogastric lavage). But in most cases, it only helps if done within an hour of your child consuming the iron. Inserting the lavage tube can cause problems, and if iron pills haven't broken down in the child's stomach, they might be too big to pass through the tube.

content_blocks.text: The first thing your doctor will do is ensure the child with iron poisoning symptoms is breathing normally. Then, they'll likely give the child a liquid (laxative) to help clean out their bowel.

Serious cases often require IV (intravenous) chelation therapy . This involves a series of IVs with deferoxamine mesylate ( Desferal ), a chemical that binds to the extra iron in the blood so your child's body can get rid of it through their pee. Doctors can also give deferoxamine as a shot, but they usually use an IV because it's easier to control the dose. Common side effects of deferoxamine treatment include red-orange pee and low blood pressure . This treatment usually lasts about 24 hours.

Your doctor may consider pumping of the stomach (orogastric lavage). But in most cases, it only helps if done within an hour of your child consuming the iron. Inserting the lavage tube can cause problems, and if iron pills haven't broken down in the child's stomach, they might be too big to pass through the tube.

content: Your child may also get breathing support from a ventilator. And doctors may do tests to check their hemoglobin (a protein found in red blood cells) if they have signs of bleeding.

If your doctor thinks your child may also have swallowed other medications , they may give them activated charcoal to drink. Activated charcoal doesn't bind to iron, but it may be useful in absorbing other medications.

sections.heading: Self-Care at Home
content: Iron poisoning is too serious to take care of at home. If you think your child has swallowed iron, call your doctor or poison control center immediately. The American Association of Poison Control Centers is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week, at 1800-222-1222.
Don't try to make your child throw up, either by hand or by using syrup of ipecac. This can make it harder for doctors to know if your child has iron poisoning.

content_blocks.text: Iron poisoning is too serious to take care of at home. If you think your child has swallowed iron, call your doctor or poison control center immediately. The American Association of Poison Control Centers is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week, at 1800-222-1222.
Don't try to make your child throw up, either by hand or by using syrup of ipecac. This can make it harder for doctors to know if your child has iron poisoning.

sections.heading: Next Steps/Prevention
content: To help protect your child against iron poisoning:
bullets: Keep all medications where children cannot get to them. Locked cabinets or containers can help keep your children safe.
Make sure childproof caps on your supplements and medications are replaced tightly each time you use them. But remember that childproof caps aren't a guarantee that children are safe.
Educate your children that some things that look like candy aren't and can be harmful.

content_blocks.text: To help protect your child against iron poisoning:
associated_bullets: Keep all medications where children cannot get to them. Locked cabinets or containers can help keep your children safe.
Make sure childproof caps on your supplements and medications are replaced tightly each time you use them. But remember that childproof caps aren't a guarantee that children are safe.
Educate your children that some things that look like candy aren't and can be harmful.

sections.heading: Outlook
content: The outlook for an iron overdose depends on how serious it is and how quickly you get treatment.

If your child has no symptoms four to six hours after eating or drinking a substance containing iron, they probably didn't consume enough to overdose. If they have digestive symptoms that get better fairly quickly, and their vital signs or normal, they'll need supportive treatment. Doctors will also need to keep an eye on them for some time.
If they have more serious symptoms or signs of blood pressure issues, they'll need aggressive treatment.
Without prompt diagnosis and treatment, iron poisoning could lead to organ failure, blocked intestines, coma, or death.

sections.heading: Iron Poisoning FAQs
content: Is iron poisonous?

Like many substances, iron can be poisonous if you take too much. Iron is an essential mineral in your body, but an iron overdose can cause serious symptoms. It can damage organs such as your liver, kidney, heart, and pancreas and can even be fatal.
What are the symptoms of too much iron in children?
Early symptoms of iron poisoning in children can include:

content: If you think your child has consumed something containing iron, call poison control or seek medical help right away.
What are the symptoms of chronic iron poisoning?

Chronic iron poisoning ( hemochromatosis or iron overload) happens when your body stores too much iron over time. This can be an inherited condition or a result of medical conditions such as liver disease . The extra iron can build up in organs such as your liver, kidneys, heart, and pancreas, leading to serious health problems. Symptoms may include:
What are the symptoms of iron poisoning in dogs?

Many people take iron supplements, as their diets lack enough iron. Taking iron may be good for most humans, but for pets, high doses of iron can irritate the gastrointestinal tract, leading to vomiting, diarrhea, and liver damage.

Dogs can get iron poisoning by taking supplements meant for humans, especially multivitamins coated in sugar that they may find tasty. Other common sources include fertilizer and the oxygen absorber packets found in dried or dehydrated dog food. Common iron poisoning symptoms in dogs include:
If you think your dog swallowed something containing iron, take them to the vet right away to prevent serious problems or even death.
bullets: Heart problems (irregular heartbeat or heart failure)

sources: Lauren Elizabeth Siewny, MD, emergency medicine specialist, assistant professor of emergency medicine, Duke University Hospital, Durham, N.C.
Odaimy Cervantes, MD, family medicine physician, Baptist Health South Florida, Miami.

meta_description: Learn the symptoms of iron poisoning, overdose risks, and treatment options to prevent complications and stay safe.
